text:
As your organization
begins to move IT infrastructure

operations to the cloud, you’ll
face a number of challenges
that need to be addressed.

The first one is transparent
tracking of cloud spend and ability
to forecast.

Shifting from more of a fixed
to a variable pricing model

requires a new muscle to be built
inside your organization.

Controls and governance
need to be re-evaluated.

The top question that I get from
CFOs is how to best manage

cloud spend to ensure they deliver
upon the cost savings expected.

AWS has great frameworks,
tools, and partners who can work

alongside of you as you go through
this journey.

These resources can help ensure
you set up the right guardrails

and principles on the frontend
to mitigate the risk of overspending
in the cloud.

The second challenge is articulating
and mitigating any risks of moving
to the cloud.

Questions that I get from CFOs
include: How do you best manage

concentration risk with a cloud
provider?

How do you ensure that your
data is secure in the cloud?

What changes (if any) are needed
to ensure compliance and regulatory
requirements are met?

Partner with your CIO, chief
procurement officer, and AWS

account team to develop your
own viewpoint on these typical

questions as they likely will
be asked by internal and external
stakeholders.

The third challenge is measuring
the return on your investment
in cloud.

It requires partnership
across the C-suite given all

the influences in both cost
and value delivered.

AWS has developed a great framework,
called the Cloud Value Framework,

to help organizations
articulate the value expected
in a cloud migration.

The five components are cost
savings, staff productivity,

operational resilience,
business agility, and sustainability.

Research from AWS shows that
less than 10 percent of the value

of a cloud migration comes
from cost savings, and business

agility delivers close to half
of the value.

Keep that in mind as you explore
your company’s transformation.

The last challenge is to address
the understanding of how cloud

investments affect financial
statements.

I get a lot of questions
from CFOs who want to better

understand how a move to the
cloud will impact their financials.
It can be confusing at times.

The move to the cloud will reduce
future upfront costs.

It will also shift IT infrastructure
costs to variable, rather
than fixed costs.

Another impact to consider
is that many organizations

can better take advantage
of research and development

tax credits for cloud investments
in some countries, which is worth

exploring with your accounting
policy team and auditors.

Overall, CFOs need to balance
the benefits of the cloud,

such as increased efficiency
and scalability, with the risks

and challenges associated
with a cloud migration.
